reviewText: Now if they just make one called Sanity Clause at Christmas.  ; ) Good story, casting, acting, and suspense.  This has more red herrings than a can could hold.  Probably one of the best things about the movie is not knowing till the last few minutes who killed everyone.  This is worth a rental for that alone.  If I saw this it must have been years ago.  It's a sleeper thriller.  Now you may not enjoy it enough to want it in your library, but I recommend you at least rent it.CA Luster

reviewText: This movie has shoes that drop all over the place.  It changes face several times and ties together nicely in the end. The dialogue is good, the acting is good, the lighting is great and the scenes take on sinister elements when needed but always hinting not giving it away.  The lead actor in this (I can't remember his name) is realistic and easy to relate to.  This is an old school mystery with a bit of Hitchcock.  I don't want to give anything away because it's just that good.  I highly recommend this movie

reviewText: Grabbed  this one purely because I needed a Kate McNeil fix. Getting harder and harder to find her these days.The poor early dialogue and overdone exposition made me think this is another cheesy cable drama, but  once the story begins to unfold (and the dialogue lessens) it really rolls  out into a darn good thriller. Many different suspects (the parents, the  friend, the lover, the co-worker), lots of motives keep you guessing.Its  no frills, you won't have anywhere near the production value of Seven,  Silence of the Lambs, or even Kiss the Girls. And try not to pay to much  attention to Andrew McCarthy, or Paul Sorvino for that matter, as their  minimalist approach to character will only distract you from the  story.Too bad this little script ultimately found itself in the  low-budget land of straight-to-video. A little TLC and a few bucks could  have paid big dividends here.All in all a very pleasant surprise.
summary: Surprise,  surprise, its really pretty good.

reviewText: If you like A. McCarthy, you owe it to yourself to rent this movie. Trouble for McCarthy starts early in the movie and gets worse as the movie progresses. McCarthy is a successful insurance consultant - seeming to live the perfect life, with a beautiful wife and two kids. The connection between his wife and McCarthy could have been developed a little more. It's a fairly good plot and script, but McCarthy adds tension to an otherwise typical movie. It resembles other movies where the man's back is against the wall and there seems to be no solution, until the end: Mel Gibson in Ransom or recently Prisoners, with Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal. The name of the movie does not really reflect what the movie is about. Insurance people in general are not a very exciting bunch. To make them seem like the bad guys is really a stretch.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The protagonist in this suspenseful mystery invents a psychological theory that saves insurance companies millions of dollars in payment for accident insurance. As a result he is raised to a high managerial position in an insurance company.He seemingly has a very satisfying marriage to a very beautiful woman, although his wife is searching for the ability to express herself and sometimes travels outside of State. He receives a telephone call from a man who says our protagonist's wife hired him to kill him, but he will not do it if he pays him twice the fee offered by his wife. Foolishly, he does not mention this to his wife. Shortly thereafter, the blackmailer and our hero's wife are murdered and our hero is suspected of the murders.The film reveals several possible reasons for the murders as well as several possible suspects. Viewers will, I think, enjoy the suspense trying to figure out if the husband committed the crimes or someone else. And if someone else who was it and why.
summary: A good suspenseful film with a surprize ending

reviewText: I agree with the other reviewer on the acting... some of which doesn't measure up to this excellent screenplay.  However, this movie is still very well put together.I was kept guessing on the murderer with this one.  There are several odd characters, with their own personal agendas, that create a very complex thriller.  Some of the acting isn't first rate, but the screenplay carries them well.I don't want to give anything away, so I'll end this here.

reviewText: The butler did it!  Er, ... I mean the character-whose-motivation-is-only-revealed-at-the-very-end did it!  Sherlock Holmes gives it two thumbs down while Watson says "I say!".The "twist ending" is a reverse deus ex machina in which the bad person's reason for being bad pops onto the stage to save all the other characters' from primary consideration.  And for some reason it is important that the insurance industry is portrayed as a bunch of hard-hearted, blame-the-victim, cognac-and-cigar-smoking rats.The only scenes in which the actors aren't stiff are the dead-body-reaction shots, someone's-going-to-pay shots, and the sex scenes (pun intended ... and yes, I like hyphens).

reviewText: Another viewer wrote, "Never got Bored!" I borrowed his line because I had the same experience!I was never bored during this film.  I talked back to the actors with suggested behaviors based on my perception  of what was happening.I loved Paul Sorvino in this role.  I have never seen him portray such a vulnerable character. As a Catholic, I was  really able to  relate to his conflict as the train approached and the child was locked (in the seat belt) in the car (something he had done to avenge the death of his wife).  He was always a favorite actor of mine.  He usually played a detective.  Today, Connie Britton is in  a weekly series called NASHVILLE. She had presence when I saw her for the first time years ago and I am D E L I G H T E D to see her in Escape Clause. Andrew McCarthy is a new name for me.  However, I will remember it and look for more films that include him.  Thanks, Mrs. I.

reviewText: The it-on what appears to be a pretty low budget movie was a couple of notches up in complexity- red herrings abounded with at least one misleading edit - it it an on-going scene ( when there did not seem to be other devices like this) or was it a flashback? I didn't know and was pretty captivated throughout. There are some fairly graphic sex scenes but they aren't really gratuitous . The only "weak" plot point is the nasty in-laws but they help add to the "this jut can't get a break" atmosphere.AND you just might find your self rooting for an insurance man!

reviewText: Have a craving to watch an old 80's 4:3 format movie? No, me neither.  The acting is really pretty terrible.  Even Paul Sorvino, whom I usually love, is pretty bad.  They are all over-acting in some cheesy made for TV kind of way.  Most of the time it feels like you're watching an overlength episode of As The World Turns or some other crappy soap opera.  Only Connie Britton manages to act without looking like a melodramatic buffoon.  In very 80's style, there's a couple minutes of gratuitous boob baring sex scenes at the beginning.
